abstract.p: This article extends a novel advanced dynamic calculation method (IDEAS – Inverse Dynamics based Energy Analysis and Simulation) of assessing the controllability of a building and its servicing systems. IDEAS allows confident (i.e. calibrated in SAP) predictions to be made regarding the impact of novel heating and renewable energy systems. IDEAS can be used as a dynamic sizing tool for a heating system in a building and can be used to benchmark control systems performance as it can represent near perfect control. The addition of an air source heat pump model to IDEAS is described. This allows for detailed analysis to be made of air source heat pumps in a SAP-compliant framework, taking into account the dynamic nature of the system efficiency and thermal capacity.

Practical applications: ASHPs are still a relatively novel technology in the UK, yet it has been suggested they could play a significant role in efforts to de-carbonise the heating sector. However field trials have found performance varies widely from installation to installation. Whilst some of this variation is due to user behaviour, ASHP systems are also very sensitive to design and commissioning. Fundamental methodologies which can provide detailed analysis of ASHP performance, such as that presented in this article, could contribute to improving system design standards. This would ensure more installations achieve a good level of performance, boosting confidence in the technology.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The European Directive on the Energy Performance of Buildings,1,2 referred to as the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive stipulates that all European member states must produce an Energy Performance Certificate (EPC) whenever buildings are constructed, sold or rented. In the UK, SAP is the procedure used to generate an EPC for all dwellings while SBEM is generally used to produce EPCs for non-domestic buildings.

Studies have shown that there can be variances in results between SAP and dynamic simulation tools.3 Simplified symbolic assessment methods have been shown to be relevant for controllability analysis4–6 and for the assessment of buildings.7 A benefit of symbolic modelling is that a symbolic model can rapidly and thoroughly determine the effect of disturbances such as free heat gains or external temperature.8 Relatively simple symbolic models are required for the buildings industry; symbolic models are powerful and have to be low order.9

Quasi-steady-state methods such as SAP and SBEM (collectively known as the National Calculation Methodologies or NCMs) would benefit by the creation of a tool to simply estimate the potential impact of innovative technologies to energy efficiency and regulation. A novel advanced dynamic calculation method (IDEAS, Inverse Dynamics based Energy Analysis and Simulation) of assessing the controllability of a building and its servicing systems has been developed. IDEAS can be used to model innovative technologies and buildings10 which are outside the scope of NCMs. The IDEAS calculation method is based upon fundamental physics to produce a simple-to-use methodology which is familiar to current users of the established NCMs. Furthermore, IDEAS has been calibrated with over a large range of test cases with SAP.11

IDEAS allows for an extension of quasi-steady-state methods in many areas, such as: the ability to make use of various dynamic climate files12 and the flexibility to amend the heating set-point which is tracked (for example, comparisons can be made between tracking a constant set-point vs a varying set-point). IDEAS has been described in depth.13,14

The focus of this article is the SAP-compliant treatment of air source heat pumps (ASHPs) using the IDEAS calculation method. An equation-fit model method is employed for the purposes. The SAP methodology is the recognised method for building professionals to meet buildings compliance and is the culmination of three decades of research commencing with BREDEM 1.15,16 ASHPs have been monitored and modelled in complex detailed dynamic simulation tools.17 Additionally, the major factors which affect the uptake of heat pump technology in the UK domestic sector have been highlighted.18

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: A SHPs present a challenge to quasi-steady-state energy estimation tools such as SAP or SBEM. In contrast with gas boilers, for example, the coefficient of performance (heat pump equivalent of efficiency; known as COP) and maximum output of a real ASHP varies considerably. The main drivers of this variation are changes in external air temperature and heating system return temperature. Quasi-steady-state energy estimation tools must reduce this transitory behaviour to representative average values. However selecting representative values is problematic, as return temperature is very sensitive to system design and specification. This is demonstrated by recent ASHP field trials, which revealed annual, whole-system COPs ranging from 1.2 to 3.2.19

An advanced calculation methodology and a dynamic framework would allow more accurate predictions of performance to be obtained. It would enable the transient nature of ASHP performance to be fully incorporated, and could take account of individual installations’ specific parameters. This could enable a more accurate analysis of the appropriateness of an ASHP for a particular dwelling, especially as localised weather profiles and tailored internal gains can be used. Furthermore, the ability to examine the transitory behaviour of an ASHP system would enable a deeper understanding of the factors affecting performance, allowing its performance to be maximised.

The IDEAS advanced calculation methodology was selected as the modelling environment for ASHPs. The main reasons were IDEAS’ calibration with SAP and the flexibility which stems from its implementation in Matlab/Simulink.11 The Matlab/Simulink environment allows full transparency of the calculation procedure as opposed to detailed DSMs, which are a complex and unfamiliar environment for many people in the buildings industry and for the majority of the users of SAP.7

sec.title: ID control theory
sec.p:
While other energy performance packages such as the NCMs consider the building to be operating in steady state, the IDEAS methodology is a dynamic model. It uses the concept of ID coupled with the RIDE perfect control algorithm.20 The use of ID and RIDE allows IDEAS to solve for the energy consumption and temperatures at each simulation time-step. This concept is illustrated in Figure 2. Figure 1.
Sample SAP calculated energy efficiency and environmental impact ratings, calculated using SAP 200932 Figure 2.
ID + RIDE illustration: calculates the necessary input based on a required output.
ID: inverse dynamics

sec.title: Building physics
sec.p:
As the IDEAS methodology has been specifically developed to test the controllability of a building, we can use a simplified approach to the representation of the building physics. This fundamental building physics model was created to represent heat transfer between the building and the outside environment. The dynamic model describes the energy and mass balance of several nodes in the building along with a heating system. In IDEAS, the building is represented as a single environmental zone consisting of four temperature nodes:
zone temperature, Tzone, which represents the air and furniture within the environmental zone;
structural temperatures, T¯si and T¯se, where the node is placed at the centre of mass of the respective portion of the building wall structure; and
internal mass temperature, Tim, which represents the temperature of the non-removable internal mass within the building such as partition walls, struts, joists, etc.

The relationship between these nodes follows the thermal resistance network shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Equivalent thermal network for building physics

IDEAS is represented in the time-domain, where it is possible to dynamically model a non-linear, time-varying, multivariable system.21 However, the case presented here is for a linear, single output system which is sufficient for the investigation of the energy performance of ASHPs. The linear differential equations representing the rate of change of the temperature nodes are derived from first principles utilising the relationships in Figure 3. These differential equations are subsequently converted into a state-space representation for controllability analysis and implementation within the Matlab/Simulink environment. The state-space representation of the system is given by (5)x·(t)=δx·(t)+x·0 (6)y(t)=δy(t)+y0where δx·(t) and δy(t) represent the small perturbation change from the initial building conditions x·0 and y0. In IDEAS, it is the small perturbation change that is simulated in order to remove the dependence on having to know the exact initial conditions of the building at the beginning of the simulation. The state-space equations (5) and (6) can now be cast as (7)δx·(t)=Aδx(t)+Bδu(t)+Eδd(t) (8)y(t)=Cδx(t)where A, B and E are the system, input and disturbance matrices, respectively. These contain the model and building parameters that influence the rate of change of the temperature nodes. The matrix C is known as the output matrix, which determines the ratio of the temperature nodes that comprises the controlled temperature.

sec.title: Controlled temperature
sec.p: Equation (6) is known as the output equation, which relates the output of the system to the state of the system. In general, the output of a system is what you wish to control (or ‘track’ in control theory terminology). In IDEAS, we have the advantage of being able to quickly change what we want to control.

The results presented in this article are based upon IDEAS tracking a comfort temperature; CIBSE Guide A22 defines an index for the comfort temperature of a hypothetical room as the operative temperature, given by (9)y(t)=Tc(t)=1/2Tzone(t)+1/2Tr(t)where Tr is the mean radiant temperature of the environmental zone. If the node is placed in the centre of this zone, this approximates to the mean surface temperature of the zone, which is given as (10)Tr=Tm=∑(AiTi)∑(Ai)

Substituting equation (10) into equation (9), and utilising the thermal resistance network (Figure 3) we arrive at the following output equation for comfort temperature (11)y(t)=[1/2+2/3(AsAim+As)(hidw4kw+hidw)]Tzone(t) +1/2(AsAim+As)(4kw4kw+hidw)Tsi¯(t) +1/2(AimAim+As)Tim(t)

sec.title: RIDE perfect control algorithm
sec.p: The RIDE theory has been successfully deployed in many areas, such as non-linear control systems for fighter aircraft,23 missiles24 and most recently in the controllability of buildings.7 IDEAS utilises the RIDE control algorithm in order to establish the heat energy required at each model time-step in order to achieve the required environmental temperature in the building zone. In this implementation, the controller is comprised of two components: a controller input δuc(t), which depends on the environmental temperature error signal; and an estimation input δueq(t), which uses full state-feedback of the systems current state and disturbances in order to compensate for slow building dynamics and disturbance rejection. These two terms working together are able to reduce the system to a linear first-order system.20 The two terms are defined by the following equations (12)δuc(t)=g(CB)-1(δr(t)-δy(t)) (13)δueq(t)=(CB)-1(CAδx(t)+CEδd(t))where g is the exponential frequency of the system, which defines the responsiveness of the system (see ‘Optimum start’ section for further discussion) and δr(t) the set-point for required environmental temperature. (CB)−1 represents the controller matrix and is what inverts the dynamics of the system as in the ‘ID control theory’ section. Therefore, the heat energy required at any time-step to move the system from its current output to the set-point temperature is given by (14)φH(t)=u(t)=δuc(t)+δueq(t)+u0where φH(t) is limited by a term, φH,max, to represent the maximum output of the heater modelled. The upper heater limit is a significant non-linearity in IDEAS. Another non-linearity is that there is no cooling, this is represented by φH,min and is set to 0 to prevent the control system from cooling. IDEAS is different from other state-space methods as it takes into account the non-linearities of the heating system.

sec.title: Optimum start
sec.p: An optimum start algorithm helps heating systems meet an intermittent demand profile by adjusting the start time of the heating system. It calculates the extra time required to reach the temperature set-point based on the responsiveness of the heating system and its size in relation to the building parameters.

An optimum start algorithm is intrinsically built in to SAP by way of a responsiveness factor, expressed as a fraction whereby a value of 1 is deemed the maximum. In order to ensure that IDEAS will correlate with SAP, it was necessary to include an analogous factor that takes into account the responsiveness of the heating system.

In IDEAS, the responsiveness factor of a system is expressed in terms of a time constant. A sample of the relative values is given in Table 1. Table 1.
System responsiveness comparison
Heating system SAP responsiveness, R IDEAS time constant, τ (s) Settling time, ts (min)
Direct acting boiler 1.0 300 15
Wood chip/pellet boiler 0.75 900 45
Fan storage heater 0.5 1800 90
Under-floor heating 0.25 3600 180
IDEAS: Inverse Dynamics based Energy Analysis and Simulation.

As shown, the larger the time constant of the heating system, the slower the system response will be. Therefore, minimal optimum start is required for fast acting heating emitters, such as gas boilers; however, it is critical for a slow acting heating emitter, such as under-floor heating. For this study, optimum start has been added for ASHP systems with both fast and slow acting heat emitters.
The RIDE control algorithm utilised in IDEAS ensures the system response to a step temperature set-point is that of a first-order system given by (15)Tei(t)=y(t)=[1-exp(-t/τ)]Tset(t)
Therefore, as t → ∞, Tei(t) → Tset(t)

Figure 4 shows the first-order system response to a unit step change in terms of the time constant. Figure 4.
First-order system response to a step input

From Figure 4, it can be seen that the time for the response to reach and stay within 5% of its final value is 3τ. Therefore, a time of 3τ from the demand time to compensate for the system lag was selected as the setback for optimum start which also calculates an additional setback in order to account for the fact that an ASHP will have an upper threshold for instantaneous power output, defined as φH,max. The optimum start time is defined, for the initial heating period at the start of the simulation, as (16)topt=tset-3τ-(1/c11)(Tset-c12x0[2]-c14x0[4])-y0a11x0[1]+a12x0[2]+a14x0[4]+b11φH,max+e11Toiwhere the terms c11,c12,c14,a11,a12,a14,b11,e11 are coefficients of the matrices. The mathematical derivation has already been published.14 Utilising these two setback parameters, the optimum start of the ASHP is dynamically calculated within IDEAS.

sec.title: Model overview
sec.p:
The development of the heating system model has been described in detail previously.25 The model is intended to represent a typical retrofit scenario, consisting of an air-to-water heat pump unit delivering heat directly to conventional central heating radiators. It is assumed that supplementary heating is provided, as is common practice; ASHP capacity is reduced in cold weather, and this ensures occupant comfort can be maintained. It also takes over from the ASHP if the return temperature from the radiators reaches the ASHP’s maximum operating temperature (assumed to be 55°C). The supplementary heating is assumed to be a 100% efficient immersion coil, fitted after the ASHP in the heating circuit. This is a common configuration in domestic ASHPs, offering the advantages of simplicity and space efficiency. The key outputs of the model are the electricity required by the ASHP unit, the heating system circulation pump and supplementary heating. A simplified schematic representation is given in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Schematic of IDEAS plus ASHP system models.
IDEAS: Inverse Dynamics based Energy Analysis and Simulation; ASHP: air source heat pump

sec.title: Radiator component
sec.p: The radiator component is required to calculate the return temperature that would result from delivering heat at rate φH, in order that the return temperature can be used in the ASHP regression models. It consists of the equation (17)Treturn=(φH17.866Arad)11.2949+Tzone-φH2m·wcp

Heat requirement φH and indoor temperature Tzone are calculated at each time-step by IDEAS. The total wall area in the building occupied by radiators Arad and the mass flow rate of water in the heating system m·w are constants which are set prior to simulations.

The basis for equation (17) is the heat transfer relation (18)φH=hradAradΔT=hradArad(Trad-Tzone)where hrad is the heat transfer coefficient between radiator surface and room. Radiator temperature is assumed to be the arithmetic mean of the flow temperatures in and out of the radiators (19)Trad=Tin+Treturn2
Tin is eliminated from equation (19) by rearranging and substituting in (20)φH=m·wcp(Tin-Treturn)
Substituting the amended equation (19) into equation (18), and solving for Treturn, gives (21)Treturn=φH(1hradArad+12m·wcp)+Tzone

A key aspect of radiator performance is that heat transfer coefficient hrad is not fixed, but varies with ΔT. Technical specifications were obtained from two radiator manufacturers for typical 0.6 m tall, double panel double convector central heating radiators.26,27 The specifications give radiator outputs at a ΔT of 50 K, tested according to BS EN 442.28 They also provide correction charts, so that outputs at other values of ΔT can be calculated. Inserting this information into equation (18), along with radiator area, allows the calculation of h across the intended operating range of ΔT. Plotting mean h against ΔT (Figure 6) and applying a least-squares fit gave the equation (22)hrad=17.866ΔT0.2949 Figure 6.
Radiator heat transfer coefficient against ΔT
Substituting this into equation (21) and eliminating Tin as before gives equation (17).

sec.title: ASHP component
sec.p: The performance of the ASHP unit is represented by two regression models. These calculate COP and maximum heat output. The form chosen for the regression models is a second-order polynomial in two variables, radiator system return temperature and external air temperature, as shown in equation (23). The choice of variables reflects the critical factors in Carnot’s theorem for the maximum efficiency of a heat engine. This method is very similar to that used in other simulations of building-integrated ASHP performance.17 (23)a0+a1T0+a2T02+a3Treturn+a4Treturn2 +a5T0Treturn

MATLAB was used to perform a least-squares linear regression. The coefficients of the regression models are given in Table 2. Table 2.

The regression models are based on published results from the independent testing of 30 heat pump units,29 and approximate the performance of an ‘average’ ASHP. Each heat pump is tested at eight different test points (Table 3), as specified in the European Heat Pump Association test regulations.30 The heat output at test point 1 was used as each heat pump’s nominal thermal capacity. Before developing regression model, each ASHP’s heat outputs were normalised against its output at test point 1. This allows the model to represent ASHPs of different sizes; the heat output regression model is multiplied by the required nominal thermal capacity. Table 3.

The final stage in the ASHP system model comprises a number of logic operations. It is assumed the power drawn by the circulation pump is dissipated as heat inside the building. The first 32.1 W of the heat demand output by IDEAS is, therefore, separated off using a conditional loop, and assigned to the circulation pump. The value of 32.1 W was chosen using an iterative approach so that, when an annual simulation is run using the SAP standard heating pattern, the total energy used by the circulation pump approximates that assumed in SAP. The remainder of the heat demand, φH* is apportioned by conditional loops to either the ASHP or the supplementary heating according to the logic in Table 4. The two conditions used ensure that supplementary heating is only drawn on when the ASHP cannot meet the heat demand on its own, either because the heat demand is greater than φASHP.max or because its maximum operating temperature has been reached. The data available and equation-fit method employed in developing the ASHP component results in the impact of on/off cycling behaviour on performance not being fully captured. Cycling could reduce the performance of oversized ASHP systems, and this is discussed in the ‘Discussion and future work’ section. Additionally at air temperatures below approximately 5°C, ice is likely to form on an ASHP’s evaporator, requiring the periodic deployment of a ‘defrost’ mechanism. The EHPA test regulations require that, where frosting of the ASHP’s evaporator occurs in a test, a whole frosting-plus-defrost period is captured. The output and COP results given in Table 3 are averages calculated over the duration of the test. The model output at each time-step of a simulation can, therefore, be seen as ‘average’ ASHP performance for the conditions, including an adjustment to take account of the fact that defrosting is periodically required.

sec.title: Results: Sensitivity study
sec.p: COP is defined here as being the whole-system COP, calculated by dividing total heat delivered to the building by the electricity used by the ASHP unit, supplementary heating and circulation pump.

sec.title: Effect of an optimum start controller to ASHP
sec.p:
Two heat pump scenarios were modelled to determine the impact of optimum start on the energy consumption and mean internal temperature of an ASHP system in a typical dwelling (structure U-value 1 W/m2K):
ASHP with a highly responsive heat emitter (wet radiators) and
ASHP with a slowly responding heat emitter (under-floor heating)
Both heat pump scenarios are modelled in IDEAS without and with optimum start.

sec.title: Highly responsive ASHP system
sec.p:
As highlighted by the similarity of the graphs in Figure 7, there is little difference in results for a highly responsive heat pump system whether optimum start is applied or not. There is only a minimal increase in overall MIT and energy consumption for the case when optimum start is employed. Figure 7.
Highly responsive ASHP system without and with optimum start.
ASHP: air source heat pump

sec.title: Slowly responsive ASHP system
sec.p:
The left graph in Figure 8 demonstrates that without the implementation of an optimum start algorithm, a poorly responsive heat pump system will not be able to meet the set-point in time. The right graph in Figure 8 demonstrates that with optimum start applied, a slowly responsive heat pump system is able to meet the required set-point in time. Figure 8.
Poorly responsive ASHP system without and with optimum start.
ASHP: air source heat pump

sec.title: Effect of heat emitter responsivity and optimum start on ASHP performance
sec.p: Following the MCS guidelines for heat pump installers,31 an ASHP was sized for a standard dwelling with a U-value of 1.0 W/m2K based upon a Sheffield UK weather location. The total radiator area and ASHP nominal capacity were sized to meet a design heat load at relevant conditions. The radiator system was designed for a flow temperature of 55.

It can be seen from Figure 9 that COP increases as the responsivity of a heat emitter decreases. If the optimum start period is longer, the ASHP is not required to heat up the building so quickly, reducing return temperature and increasing the COP. As one would expect, heat delivered increases as the optimum start increases, due to the heat being delivered into the building for longer. However, the total electricity can be seen to decrease as the time constant increases: this is due to the improved COP of the ASHP. Figure 9.
Effect of heat emitter responsivity and optimum start on ASHP performance.
ASHP: air source heat pump

This analysis suggests that ASHPs could generally perform better if a set-point is tracked which is constant rather than intermittent. Further analysis is required to assess this over a range of cases and design parameters.

sec.title: Use of IDEAS to assist in correctly sizing a heat pump system
sec.p:
Figure 10 demonstrates the transient output from IDEAS for an undersized heat pump over 2 days, tracking an intermittent heating profile. It can be seen that the selected heat pump is undersized for the building in question, and cannot provide enough power to the heating system for the demand profile to be met. Figure 10.
Undersized ASHP (3 kW) in a poorly insulated dwelling.
ASHP: air source heat pump

IDEAS could be used to correctly size any heating system, based upon the specific parameters entered for a particular building such as areas and U-values. This is an extension of quasi-steady-state methods where the detailed sizing of heating systems and in particular the analysis of transitory response of that heating system is not possible.

sec.title: Effect of radiator size on ASHP performance
sec.p:
UK guidelines28 advise ASHP installers to size ASHP units and radiator systems so that they can meet 100% of a building’s design heat load at a chosen radiator temperature. IDEAS can been used to examine the effect of the radiator temperature selected on annual COP. Following the principles of the UK guidelines, equation (18) was used to calculate the total radiator area required to achieve each of the design radiator temperatures in Table 5. The regression model for ASHP maximum output was used to calculate the appropriate nominal ASHP capacity required. Table 5.

The results of simulations run using a version of IDEAS with a highly responsive ASHP system and a building structure U-value of 1 W/m2K appear in Table 5. The resulting COPs agree well with the results of the EST field trial,19 which found COPs in the range 1.8–3.2. Significant electricity savings could be made by sizing ASHP systems for a 35°C radiator temperature, however, the total radiator area required increases significantly.

sec.p:

To illustrate this, the electricity demand data were split according to the off-peak periods of a number of different electricity tariffs (Table 6). sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article illustrates the use of IDEAS to analyse the performance of ASHP systems. The modular and open design of the IDEAS method has been demonstrated by the addition of ASHP and radiator models with an optimum start algorithm.

This study highlighted the importance of the method employed in IDEAS: once perfect control is achieved the theoretical maximum performance of a heating system is given. Knowledge of the theoretical maximum COP would be very useful from a building services engineer perspective, and would assist with sizing. From this theoretical maximum, it would then be possible to degrade the performance by the use of factors relating to the characteristics of a particular installation – for example, whether or not load compensation is used. This methodology is a good fit with that employed by UK NCMs.

The effect of an optimum start controller to ASHP heating systems is highlighted by comparing simulations of fast and slow emitters. It is shown that an optimum start controller is not required for a fast ASHP emitter but is necessary for an emitter which responds slowly. Optimum start will help a heater met a set-point in time, with the effect of increased energy use and increased temperature in the zone.
The COPs output by the ASHP model are within the range of those found in field trials. The effect on COP of changing system parameters such as the total area of radiators installed has been shown.

This study has suggested where symbolic modelling and predictive assessment of ASHPs can be used to empower the building services engineer with detailed building specific data; details can be provided on critical aspects such as dynamic carbon intensity analysis, COP performance, ASHP and radiator sizing.

sec.title: Discussion and future work
sec.p: The main benefits of the advanced modelling of ASHPs in IDEAS are to the building professional who wishes to quickly gauge the transient and yearly impact of installing an ASHP in the UK. This is not possible in NCMs, as the quasi-steady-state approach used does not process and output data at a time-step lower than 1 month. The added flexibility of the modelling of ASHPs in IDEAS includes the ability to use user-generated heating or free heat profiles, and local weather profiles. This will allow the practitioner to determine if an ASHP is appropriate to install in various parts of the UK. Also, allowing the practitioner to use the IDEAS tool with varying free heats allows the appropriateness of an ASHP to be determined based upon the proposed use of a building: the suitability of an ASHP could vary dramatically if, for example, the occupants are retired rather than working.

Due to the importance of the tool used to model buildings in the future, recent research demonstrates the importance closing the gap between designed and built performance.33 Methods such as IDEAS can be an important part of this discussion and can suggest how NCMs could evolve in the future. The IDEAS method could be adapted to form the framework for a NCM compliant design tool; additional research and discussion is required to determine if this would be welcomed by building professionals and what form it should take.

The ASHP model could be developed further to take into account the effect on performance of part load operation and cycling. Recent work suggests the impact of cycling is generally small, but becomes marked when cycle length decreases below a certain level.34 The emergence in the domestic market of inverter-driven, variable capacity heat pumps is also relevant, as these could greatly reduce cycling behaviour.

An additional area for further development of the ASHP component is to account for the effect of varying humidity levels and frosting on performance. Ice formation on the ASHP’s evaporator coil, as well the ‘defrosting’ mechanisms implemented to deal with it, can reduce ASHP performance when air temperatures fall below approximately 5°C. The EHPA test procedure is designed so that when frosting of the ASHP occurs during a test, the effect of it and the associated defrost period on performance is captured. Some amount of frosting behaviour is, therefore, assumed in the model. Frosting is also affected by humidity as well as air temperature, and the EHPA test points do not provide enough variation for humidity to be included as a predictor variable in the regression models. It has been suggested that ASHP performance can drop if very high humidity combines with air temperatures close to zero.35

The effect of optimum start on a building’s energy use and temperature levels can be researched further along with the development of an optimum stop procedure. Additionally, the sensitivity results presented can be built upon to include a more detailed assessment of ASHP emissions using dynamic carbon intensity, ASHP sizing and the effect of radiator size to ASHP performance.
